race.name: Dead Swede Gravel
race.tagline: Northern Wyoming high plains gravel in Sheridan ranch country.

climate.description: High plains conditions with variable weather and wind.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through ranch country with Bighorn Mountains backdrop. Moderate elevation with open terrain.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Small grassroots Wyoming event. Remote ranch country setting but very limited infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: Dead Swede Gravel is a small grassroots gravel race in northern Wyoming ranch country. Sheridan is a small city with decent amenities, but the race itself is a tiny regional event with minimal infrastructure. The high plains scenery with Bighorn Mountains backdrop is beautiful, but it's remote with a small field and basic organization.
weaknesses: Small field with no competitive depth
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A small local gravel race in remote Wyoming ranch country. Perfect for locals or those seeking a Wyoming high plains experience. Not worth the long drive for most riders unless you're combining with Wyoming tourism.

final_verdict.one_liner: Small grassroots Wyoming ranch country ride with remote location.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Only if you're in Wyoming or seeking a remote high plains experience. Not worth traveling far for.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Wyoming events: other regional events. For similar ranch country vibes: Montana or Colorado high plains events.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Sheridan has basic lodging. Small city with limited options.
logistics.food: Small city with basic dining. Stock up beforehand.

history.origin_story: Grassroots gravel event in northern Wyoming ranch country.

course_description.character: High plains gravel through ranch country with mountain views.
course_description.signature_challenge: Wyoming high plains wind and open terrain.

non_negotiables.why: Wyoming high plains means significant wind exposure.
Remote location and minimal support mean managing your own nutrition and mechanicals.

topics.wind: Riding in Wyoming high plains wind

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of Wyoming high plains gravel in ranch country.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Small grassroots event in remote Sheridan.

logistics.explanation: Packet pickup requires day-before arrival only, which Anonymous notes 'pretty much requires that participants book some form of lodging for one night.' Registration via ItsYourRace works fine, and one rider confirms the process 'from registration to packet pickup to post meal collection was seamless.' Still no airport or parking details published.

length.explanation: Heidi finished the 40-mile course in 2:26 after 'a solo time trial effort over most of the course,' placing 13th overall out of 330+ racers. Jeffrey's 100-mile took 8:45 total time with 'about 1.5 hours before the DNF cutoff' at the final aid station. Multiple distances accommodate different ambitions without overwhelming terrain.

technicality.explanation: Heidi successfully descended at 43mph on loose gravel using a 2012 cyclocross bike with cantilever brakes and 32mm tires, noting 'I railed the descents.' Jeffrey describes one climb as '9-12% max grade for about a quarter mile' marked with a 'can we still be friends' sign. Challenging but manageable on standard gravel setups.

elevation.explanation: The 100-mile course climbs to 6,516 feet with Jeffrey noting 'long grindy uphills' throughout his 103-mile route. Heidi describes the 40-mile as starting with 'eight miles of pavement to get us warmed up' before hitting 'the first big climb of the day' immediately on gravel. Steady climbing without soul-crushing mega-ascents.

climate.explanation: Weather swings wildly year to year. Heidi's 2019 race was blazing hot: 'The still air combined with my black skin suit and hot sun made me want to melt.' Jeffrey's 2022 featured 'amazing weather, low 50s to start, mid 70s in afternoon' but rain dumped 2.5 inches the day before, forcing course changes.

altitude.explanation: Starting from Sheridan at ~3,800 feet and climbing toward the Bighorn Mountain foothills, Jeffrey's 100-mile reached 6,516 feet maximum elevation. Sea-level riders will notice the thinner air but won't need oxygen therapy. High enough to affect performance, manageable enough to keep racing.

adventure.explanation: The course turns 'north onto the gravel nestled along the base of the Bighorn Mountains' with minimal dust conditions, possibly from road oil treatment or recent rain. One rider loved starting 'at Kendrick Park, right there in the heart of town' with horses 'grazing on the hillside overlooking the park.' Wyoming backcountry through terrain most never see.

prestige.explanation: Jeffrey finished 64th out of 65 finishers in the 100-mile, spending most of the race dead last with a sweeper truck following him. Heidi notes the mass start crowd was 'mostly filled with people that have never road raced or ridden in a peloton.' Self-proclaimed 'Premier Gravel Race of the West' without competitive depth to support the claim.

race_quality.explanation: Aid stations every 10-12 miles offer pickle juice shots, bacon, and PBR with volunteers providing 'cheers and cowbells and offers to feed me' according to Jeffrey. Course changes happen when weather demands it - the single-track mountain section was eliminated in 2022 due to snow. Functional organization with weather flexibility.

experience.explanation: Heidi finished prouder than she'd 'been in a long time, or even never' after her second-place women's finish. The finish line features 'cheering crowds, a band in the amphitheater, and the smell of delicious barbecue' with free race beer. Solid Wyoming gravel touring without standout memorable moments.

community.explanation: The event 'has crazy huge women's fields' per Heidi, with 330+ riders in just the 40-mile distance. Aid station volunteers 'got all whoop-y and jumpy' when they realized Jeffrey was attempting the full 100-mile. Organizers ban course support vehicles 'for rider safety, and to minimize dust' creating a more controlled racing environment.

field_depth.explanation: Jeffrey rode 'almost all of the hundred miles solo' and was 'In. Fact. DFL' by mile 20, finishing 64th of 65 riders with a sweeper truck escort. While field sizes reach 330+ in shorter distances, competitive depth remains shallow. Large participation numbers don't translate to racing quality at the sharp end.

value.explanation: $100 entry includes Dead Swede t-shirt, sticker, and pint glass with well-stocked aid stations every 10-12 miles featuring bacon and beer. Free finish line barbecue, live band, and race beer complete the package. Solid bang for buck accessing Bighorn Mountain foothills terrain that would cost serious gas money to explore solo.

expenses.explanation: Sheridan, Wyoming keeps lodging and dining costs reasonable, though day-before packet pickup 'pretty much requires' overnight accommodation. The $100 entry fee won't strain anyone's budget. Equipment needs stay modest - Heidi succeeded on a 2012 cyclocross bike with narrow tires, proving expensive gravel setups aren't required.
